partintro.para: Programming and Linux are two good friends, begin with installing Linux on your PC, with the help of your mentor!

section.title: Good beginning
section.para: If you alreay have Linux on your PC then you can read further, if you don't then scroll back!

section.title: The first day – Hello, World!
section.para: We begin with this C++ source code (which was for example given to Gréta in the greta1.cpp file).

section.title: Dad – mentor
section.para:
It is true for the programmer, too, that generally he/she stands on the shoulders of giants
The great scientist, Isaac Newton wrote this (in his letter written to Robert Hook) to express that he could also build upon the work of others: "If I have seen further it is by standing on the sholders of Giants".
, in other words, he or she reuses other programmers' programs. The #include command does exactly this, it pastes the iostream programs written by others. In this iostream there are programs that materialize the channels. For example your program will have a channel
Where does this channel come from? On your machine (or for example on your phone or even on your tablet) there is a special program, called the operating system, the Linux kernel, which Linus Torvalds started to write when he was on a university in Finnland. The operating system is a good friend of the programmer, this program guarantees fro example these channels, too.
, whereto your program sends the letters, and these letters will be displayed on the screen.

The basic foundation of a C++ program is the function, this has a first line, which is now the int main() line. This is made of three parts: it tells what the function will calculate: this is now a number, the int keyword means this. The second part is the name of the function, this in our case is main. The third part is written between parantheses: the function receives what is here, it has to calculate from these . In our case this part is empty, in other words we didn't give the function anything as an input.

The body of the function is the block, which is a list of commands written between curly braces. Every command ends with a semicolon. We have now two commands. The first one is the one called std::cout which prints the "Hello, Vilag!" text to output channel. The input part of this channel is in our program and the output part is opened to the screen. Then we print a special signal, which makes the cursor jump to a new line on the screen.

The second command is the return which gives back the value calculated by the function to the caller of the function. We didn't calculate anything now, only printed to the screen, so we returned 0. This means by convention that everything was okay with the program, because the caller of your main function was the operating system itself, the kernel of the Linux, the program indicates that it didn't have any problems. With this, the main function ended and with that our program finished.
Now let us try out the program!

First, we translate the source code so that the processor of our machine understands it. We save this translation in the greta1 file with the g++ compiler. Then by writing its name after the dot slash we run the compiled program. Running a program is the process when the processor reads the compiled program.

What happened after pressing enter after typing dot slash and the filename? The main function was executed, which printed the Hello, World! text to the output channel, which was therefore displayed on the screen.

important.title: The language of the processor
important.para:
The machines do not understand the various C++ source codes, but the C++ programmers do! The source code must be compiled to the processor's own language. This is executed by the g++compiler program
The g++ compiler was written by a famous programmer who has a well-known hacker name: RMS, in other words Richard Matthew Stallman. If in your dreams you found yourself in the world of The Lord of The Rings as Frodo, then he will be Gandalf. :)
. You don't have to worry, the g++ program is already on your computer, it has been helping the Linux since a very long time!
Your mentor can show you what the language that your processor understands actually looks like: it is made of numbers. Here is for example the runnable code compiled from you first program:
... because this continues on more displays! You can see that the language of your processor is not understandable for the C++ programmers.

important.title: The programmer manual of Linux
important.para: Previously we saw the contents of the greta1 file with the hexdump command: $ hexdump -v -e '/1 "%02X "' greta1 | more but don't think that I can write these things immediately! Simply I just check them in the manual.

In the world of C programming, it is even more of a daily routine to check what you have to use in the manual and see how you can make it work! This is a written profession, it was not given to us by God, it was invented by engineers, this is the simple truth: you only have to read it. For example take a look at what the manual says about the std::cout object:
important.screen:
std::cout(3) C++ Programmer's Manual std::cout(3)
NAME std::cout - Standard output stream
TYPE object
SYNOPSIS #include <iostream>
extern ostream cout;
DESCRIPTION Object of class ostream that represents the standard output stream oriented to narrow characters (of type char). It corresponds to the C stream stdout. ...

section.title: Gréta
section.para: The processor counts numbers and prints the letters to the std::cout . The g++ compiles the program. The iostream is a channel. The #include pastes others' code into yours. The 0 means that your program executed successfully.

section.title: Nándi
section.para: The g++ translates to the processor's language. The #include is a command, which tells the computer to copy other's code into yours. The cout is a channel for letters to cross it. The << means that push the letters in this direction. The 0 means that the main function was executed properly.

section.title: Matyi
section.para: The #include is the first command. With the #include we paste into other programs. The iostream is a channel. The int main is the main function. The main function is called by the operating system. The function means that it is a building block of the program. std::cout << Hello World << std::endl This means that we print the letters to the channel. The std::endl means that the cursor goes to the next line. The return returns a number to the caller of the function. The return 0; means that the program finished successfully.

section.title: Second day – for loop
section.para: We improve our first program, so that we can get this second one:

section.title: Dad – mentor
section.para: With the for statement we can repeat things, in other words we can make iterations in our program. The iteration means that we execute something (the thing that we iterate) over an over again, multiple times (it can even be 0: 0 or infinite).
Generally, a for loop looks like this for(starting point; how many times; ending point) {we iterate what is here}.

In the second source we iterate a whole number int i starting from the value of i=0 (initialising) and we continue until it is true that i<3, so the i variable takes on the values 0, 1 and 2, printing them in this order.

section.title: Gréta
section.para: The for is a loop. The for starts from i=0 and iterates while i<3 is true.

section.title: Nándi
section.para: The for repeats the loop. The for is a loop. What does a loop mean? Do one push-up then 10 push-ups. The 10 push-ups are a loop from 1 to 10.

section.title: Matyi
section.para:
The for is a loop. It is a loop because it executes the program multiple times. The ++i means that we increase the value of i by 1. For example if i equals 1 then
++i=2
++i=3
++i=4.
If there was a curly brace next to the for statement then there would be more commands. The i=0 is where the iteration starts, the i<3 shows how long it will iterate and the ++i shows by how many it increases on every iteration.

section.title: Third day – multiplication table
section.para:
The children solved a task: let's modify the program 2 so that it prints the 7 times table, i.e. we must reach this output:
1 * 7 = 7 2 * 7 = 14 3 * 7 = 21 . . . 10 * 7 = 70

section.title: Dad – mentor
section.para: On paper we discussed briefly that the first number changes just like the for loop variable i, the other number is always 7, in turn. We can define the latter one for example as int m = 7;. We talked over the printing separately, that the first number is always i, the second one is m, the third one is the multiplication of the two, i.e. later at the computer we can write something like this: cout << i << "*" << m << i*m << endl;.

section.title: Nándi
section.para: The task from yesterday started from Matyi's for-like solution, it was gone fast
it was only needed to modify the upper bound of the loop to the right solution.
Nándi got an inkling of how stuff is going, he made the maximum of the task: he printed the times table to 10000, then he wanted to tweak the for loop as:
section.screen: $ g++ nandi2.cpp -o nandi2 $ ./nandi2 Nandi multiplication table $

section.title: Matyi
section.para: After the undermentioned unsuccessul attempt
independently from Nándi (they were just programming in different rooms) he reached the right result through the same way.

section.title: Task
section.para:
Let's modify the program so that instead of the multiplication table it produces the first 10 square numbers! I.e. it gives the undermentioned output:
1 * 1 = 1 2 * 2 = 4 3 * 3 = 9 . . . 10 * 10 = 100

section.title: Nándi
section.para: He started very well:
section.screen: nandi2.cpp:5:17: error: ‘i’ was not declared in this scope long int m =i;

section.title: Matyi
section.para: The i*i is a great idea, but it was enough
because this yields a syntactic error.
section.screen: matyi2.cpp:6:17: error: expected primary-expression before ‘;’ token for(int i=1<; i<11 ; ++i)
section.para: There is an unnecessary character in the first part of the for loop declaration, furthermore the program cannot understand the int i=1<i<11; statement.

After this, he solved the task in a way mentioned earlier regarding Nándi, and he maxed out too this loop with pushing the upper limits higher. Of course, after some time this lead to overflow, which they could notice from the negative numbers in the multiplications.

section.title: Fourth day – class
Matyi
section.para: The class is a class. The class is a group of data and functions. What does a soldier have? Life, damage and name.
When does a soldier live? When his/her life is more than 0. The lives function gives information about this. The lives function tells whether the soldier lives or not to its caller.
There are more channels. The name of one of these is: iostream and an other one is the ostream.

How many lives and how much damage does a soldier have? Nándi's life is 100 and his damage is 10. The Barbarian has 80 life and 5 damage. We give these to the constructor. We talk about a constructor when the name of the function and the class is the same.
Finally, we print the name of the winner soldier to the channel. The return returns a number to the operating system.

section.title: Ötödik nap – veszélyes vizeken
section.para: Alakítsuk át kicsit a nandi4.cpp forrást: tegyünk bele némi nyomkövetést, azaz olyan kiírásokat a képernyőre, amik segítenek látni, mi történik a programban.

section.title: Apa – mentor
section.para: Mire számítunk? Az en katona objektum (Nandi) lenyomja az ellen katona objektumot (a Barbar-t). A harmadik katona objektum (Giant) lenyomja az en objektumot, majd a két győztes: en és harmadik játszik, ahol harmadik nyer.

section.para: Ezzel szemben mit mutatnak a nyomkövető üzenetek, mi is történt? A harmadik katona objektum (Giant) lenyomja az en (Nandi) objektumot. Aztán a már meggyengült en katona objektumot (Nandi-t) lenyomja az ellen objektum (a Barbar). Majd a két győztes: ellen és harmadik játszik, ahol harmadik nyer. Hát nem pontosan erre számítottunk, ugye?

A magyarázat: mi feltettük amikor fejben játszottuk le, hogy először a harcol(en, ellen) játszódik le, majd a harcol(en, harmadik) és végül a két győztes játszik. Lehet van olyan gép, ahol ez pont így lenne, viszont az enyémen pont nem így lett! Ez azért van, mert a C++ nyelv nem határozza meg a függvényhívás bemenő paramétereinek kiértékelési sorrendjét. Esetünkben, hogy a külső harcol föggvény a jobb oldali vagy a bal oldali harcol hívás végrehajtásával kezdődik-e. Mivel nincs meghatározva az egyik gépen lehet így lesz, a másikon meg máshogy. Ezért hajózunk máris veszélyes vizeken. Mit tehet a programozó? Mit kell tennie a programozónak? El kell kerülnie az olyan források írását, amelyekben ilyen szituk előfordulnak. Erre több lehetőség is adódik, hogy a programozó melyikkel él, az majd stílus kérdése lesz. Most elég annyit tudni, hogy a C++ nem a homokozó (mert például a Java vagy a C sharp az) abban az értelemben, hogy a programozó nemcsak pontosan tudhatja, mi történik programja hatására a memóriában a program objektumaival, hanem pontosan tudnia is kell!

section.para: De Matyi nem akarta, hogy a végén a Matyi név-tulajdonságú objektum önmagával harcoljon... a következő próbálkozásaik arról szóltak, hogy a végén a Matyi objektum győzzön, de ne magával harcoljon. Próbálkozást próbálkozás követett, de a többiek örömére egyszer a Gréta, máskor a Nándi objektum győzött, s persze párszor visszaköszönt a Matyi önmagával való harca is, mire belátta, hogy vannak olyan feladatok, amelyek megadott keretek között megoldhatatlanok. (Mert ha az első meccset Matyi elveszti, akkor a másodikba már nem élve megy, így nem kerül a döntőbe. Ha ez nem teljesül, azaz az elsőt nyeri, de a másodikat bukja, akkor a döntőbe kerül már eleve nem élve.)
Elevenítsük fel a következő pontban az egyik Gréta által bedobott feladatot!

blockquote.para: „Másik feladat, hogy amikor a katonák harcolnak és ha valamelyik győz, akkor újra megkapja az életét.”
